awd_abstract_narration:
Today, we are faced with three apparently conflicting problems: users are afraid to collaborate unless they have fine-grained control over how their data are accessed by others; many shared environments, especially the new ones, do not offer such controls because of the difficulty of implementing them; those that do offer such controls provide access mechanisms that are difficult to understand and use and result in users being assigned wrong access rights.  In this project the PI will investigate the idea of using special-purpose collaborative environments to distribute access, with the goal of developing a general model of access distribution that captures in-use and promising mixed-initiative schemes that have so far been defined only in an application-dependent fashion.  The model will be defined using several new kinds of application-independent objects such as access requests and grants that capture the information exchanged in a mixed-initiative system.  It will be compatible with existing authorization models including object-based models, in which copies of objects are granted, and rights-based models such as role-based access control, in which (potentially revocable) rights to the object granted.  In the PI's approach, the initiative in distributing access rights to shared objects can be taken by information guardians, information consumers, and tools that act as agents of the guardians and the consumers.  Information consumers are responsible for sending access requests to information guardians; their agents will (partially or completely) automate this task for them.  Information guardians are responsible for authorizing access; their agents will automate this task for them.  The PI will identify a general architecture for implementing his model, in which the access-awareness in existing collaboration and communication tools is kept low.  In addition, the PI will develop programming abstractions that make it easy to implement the model using the architecture.   He will use the abstractions to add mixed-initiative access control in several target systems, which will include both complex widely-used traditional file systems and distributed web services; this experience will help the PI evaluate the programmability of the abstractions.  Finally, he will perform field and lab studies to compare alternative approaches to distribute access supported by the general model. 

Broader Impacts:  If successful, this work will open up a new research area focusing on collaborative mixed-initiative access control, and show that collaborative systems are not only a liability for access control but also an asset.  Project outcomes will lead to significant improvement in the usability and programmability of fine-grained authorization mechanisms, thereby facilitating a large number of collaborations that would otherwise not take place. They will also afford a better understanding of the similarities and differences between different access distribution schemes and the consequences of using them.  In the short term, the project will develop research and teaching software consisting of two main components: layers on top of widely-used file systems that provide several new access distribution schemes, which can be evaluated by usability researchers and demonstrated in classes on security; and programming abstractions allowing the incorporation of these schemes in new shared environments implemented using web services, which can be used in both class and research projects.

Access control is the problem of ensuring that our collaborators get exactly the information they need – no more, no less. Thus, it tries to enforce the “need to know” principle. Users often do not make the effort required to implement this principle, and either overshare or under-share. Moreover, they make errors. Several dramatic incidents indicate this problem. 9/11 underscored lack of sharing of information with those who needed to know it. In response, the level of sharing was increased, which resulted in Wikileaks. Exclusion of authorized users and inclusion of unauthorized users can also occur when information is communicated via email or social networks. CBS News’s political director accidentally sent an uncomplimentary email about Congresswoman Bachmann to her campaign. There are numerous new stories of people being fired or not hired or because of over-sharing in Facebook posts. Thus, a solution to this problem can have a broad impact. In this project, we investigated the use of machine intelligence to help users enforce the "need to know" principle.

An important element of access-control is access-lists. In Facebook, these are called friend-lists. We have developed a connection-based approach for recommending friend-lists, which assumes that members of a group will have stronger connections to each other than those outside the group. Our results, in the words of one of our subjects, were “scary good”. This work was published in three refereed papers and two undergraduate theses. It resulted in the first published algorithm for predicting user-centered groups. A video of this work is at https://youtu.be/FOMSVALrdGs.

Friend-lists in social groups correspond to contact-groups in email. Email messages implicitly imply Facebook-like friend relationships, which can be mined to create contact-groups. This intuition was behind another successful algorithm we created. This work was published in two refereed papers, a Ph.D. thesis, and an undergraduate honors thesis. A video of this work is at: https://youtu.be/5u2Fb0be1lM.

The algorithms above group users based on friend-like connections. Users are also implicitly grouped together when they perform actions together, such as receiving the same shared communication or responding to, commenting on, or voting on the same posts or messages. We improved our algorithms using such bursts in collaborative activities. This work was published in a Ph.D. thesis.

Friend-lists in social groups correspond to contact-groups in email. Email messages implicitly imply Facebook-like friend relationships, which can be mined to create contact-groups. This intuition was behind another successful algorithm we created. This work was published in two refereed papers, a Ph.D. thesis, and an undergraduate honors thesis. A video of this work is at: https://youtu.be/5u2Fb0be1lM.
The algorithms above group users based on friend-like connections. Users are also implicitly grouped together when they perform actions together, such as receiving the same shared communication or responding to, commenting on, or voting on the same posts or messages. We improved our algorithms using such bursts in collaborative activities. This work was published in a Ph.D. thesis. 
Groups are not static, and evolve as our social graphs change. We developed an approach for recommending how existing groups should change. We found that our evolution recommendation algorithm always performed better than manual evolution, and recommendation of completely new groups on an evolution performed  better than evolution recommendation when the graph grew by more than 50% (because evolution recommendation does not correctly identify the new groups created in this "revolutionary" change). This work was published in a refereed paper and a Ph.D. thesis. 
Group evolution is an issue when static groups are created. An alternative is to create groups dynamically, when a message is sent, based on the history of past messages and similarity of the current and past messages. We found that group-based prediction outperformed content-based prediction. We improved on group-based prediction by developing an algorithm for predicting a hierarchical recipient list. Our analysis found that hierarchical recommendation greatly reduces recipient-specification effort because of the ability to select multiple entries with one click. This work was published in a refereed paper and a Ph.D. thesis. 
Recipients can be also grouped and recommended in social forums such as Usenet and StackOverflow. In Usenet, the recipients are denoted by newsgroups and in StackOverflow by message tags. We applied our algorithms also to these two domains. This work was published in a Ph.D. thesis.
